prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for buying pregnant wife yoga pass for her birthday
My wife is 16 weeks pregnant.  She has a something called hypermesis which is "morning sickness" all the time, even waking up in the middle of the night to vomit.   I told her to ask her doctor for a medical leave so she is currently on temporary disability.  She stays in bed most of the day and only leaves the house to go to the hospital where she gets IV fluids for dehydration/vitamin deficiency.     
I know I always feel better when I exercise and it helps with depression.  I think she is getting depressed because she misses her job.  I think she should leave the house and get some fresh air and stretch, so I got her a yoga pass for her birthday.   I researched local studios and found one that had prenatal yoga.   When she got the email gift certificate while I was at work, she didn't call to say thank you.  When I got home, I asked her if she got the email and she just gave me a look.  I could tell she didn't like my present.  She says she is too sick to do yoga.   Ok, maybe.   She thinks it is a rude present and that I am "tone deaf."  I can get her another present...don't know what.   I don't think my present makes me a bad person, though.   She might feel better soon and want to take yoga classes.  She told her friends about it and they agreed with her that I am being an asshole.  I think it is rude to be so critical of my present.
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the person who bought their pregnant wife a prenatal yoga pass is in the wrong. The wife has hypermesis, which is severe morning sickness causing constant nausea and vomiting, even waking up at night. She's on temporary disability, stays in bed most of the day, and only goes to the hospital for IV fluids. The husband thought she might benefit from yoga to help with depression from missing work, but she was upset and called him "tone deaf." Her friends agreed she's right.

Hmm. The husband's intention was good—he wanted her to get fresh air and exercise, which he found helpful for his own depression. But considering her current condition, maybe yoga isn't the best suggestion. If she's bedridden and too sick to leave, forcing her to attend classes could be insensitive. The key here is whether the gift was appropriate given her medical state. Prenatal yoga requires some level of physical ability and energy, which she might not have. Plus, she's already stressed by her illness, and the gift might feel dismissive of her needs. The husband didn't consider her perspective; he assumed yoga would help without checking if she wanted it. Even if the intention was good, the action might have overlooked her current health limitations. So, maybe he's in the wrong for not being more empathetic to her situation. Answer A.
